distribution.text: Copyright Â© Red Hat, Inc. All rights reserved.

notes.text:
An update for mod_perl is now available for Red Hat Enterprise Linux 6.

Red Hat Product Security has rated this update as having a security impact of Important. A Common Vulnerability Scoring System (CVSS) base score, which gives a detailed severity rating, is available for each vulnerability from the CVE link(s) in the References section.
notes.title: Topic

notes.text:
Mod_perl incorporates a Perl interpreter into the Apache web server, such that the Apache HTTP server can directly execute Perl code.

Security Fix(es):

* mod_perl: arbitrary Perl code execution in the context of the user account via a user-owned .htaccess (CVE-2011-2767)

For more details about the security issue(s), including the impact, a CVSS score, and other related information, refer to the CVE page(s) listed in the References section.
notes.title: Details

document.title: Red Hat Security Advisory: mod_perl security update

notes.text: mod_perl 2.0 through 2.0.10 allows attackers to execute arbitrary Perl code by placing it in a user-owned .htaccess file, because (contrary to the documentation) there is no configuration option that permits Perl code for the administrator's control of HTTP request processing without also permitting unprivileged users to run Perl code in the context of the user account that runs Apache HTTP Server processes.
notes.title: Vulnerability description

notes.text: mod_perl: arbitrary Perl code execution in the context of the user account via a user-owned .htaccess
notes.title: Vulnerability summary

notes.text: The default configurations shipped in Red Hat Enterprise Linux 6 and Red Hat Software Collections are not vulnerable to to this flaw.  The UserDir option needs to be enabled as well as AllowOverride being set to values other than "None" for this to potentially pose a threat.
notes.title: Statement

notes.text: The CVSS score(s) listed for this vulnerability do not reflect the associated product's status, and are included for informational purposes to better understand the severity of this vulnerability.
notes.title: CVSS score applicability

remediations.details:
For details on how to apply this update, which includes the changes described in this advisory, refer to:

https://access.redhat.com/articles/11258
Disabling the UserDir directive and also setting AllowOverride None should prevent the processing of perl in user .htaccess files.

vulnerabilities.title: mod_perl: arbitrary Perl code execution in the context of the user account via a user-owned .htaccess
